content: The "Job Creation Economic Stimulus Act of 2008" includes the adoption of the High Productivity Investment Deduction under section 168A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The High Productivity Investment Deduction allows taxpayers to treat the cost of certain high productivity property as an expense, not a capital cost. This deduction applies to various types of electronic and computer equipment, as well as computer software and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. The High Productivity Investment Deduction applies to equipment used in the manufacture of semiconductors, high technology medical equipment, advanced technology communications equipment, optical fiber and photonics equipment, advanced environmental products, advanced life science products, or new high productivity assets. The term 'computer' refers to a programmable electronically activated device capable of accepting information, applying processes to it, and providing the results. The term 'computer related peripheral equipment' refers to auxiliary machines designed to be controlled by a computer's central processing unit. 'Computer based machinery' includes machines that perform cutting, shaping, drilling, and other functions. The term 'electronic diagnostic equipment' refers to equipment that uses electronic components to sense or monitor various characteristics, while 'electronic control equipment' refers to equipment that responds to electronically stored information and programmed commands for material transformation or handling. Electronic control equipment electronically controls pressure, temperature, size, volume, composition purity, or other characteristics. High technology medical equipment includes electronic, electromechanical, or computer-based equipment used in patient screening, monitoring, diagnosis, or treatment. Advanced technology communications equipment is used for voice, data, video, paging, messaging, or other communication services. The curr_chunk discusses packet technology for communication services, optical fiber and photonics equipment, advanced environmental products, and advanced life sciences products. The curr_chunk defines "advanced life sciences products" as polymer, ceramic, or high-purity glass products used in biological research, and "new high productivity assets" as assets utilizing technological or scientific processes not in common commercial use before January 1, 2007. The Secretary will establish procedures for taxpayers to seek rulings on qualifying assets. The curr_chunk discusses the exclusion criteria for high productivity property, such as vehicles controlled by electronic equipment and entertainment equipment. An election under this section must be made for each taxable year. The election under this section must be made on an asset-by-asset basis on the taxpayer's tax return for the year. Special rules exclude certain property costs and apply antichurning rules for property acquired after December 31, 2007. The taxpayer or a related person must own or use the property during 2007, without changing the user, leasing it to a related person, or acquiring it without changing the user. Applicable cost recovery rules apply to property not covered by this section. Special rules state that property is not considered owned before being placed in service, and changes in property user are determined by the Secretary's regulations. The Secretary will provide regulations for recapturing deductions under subsection (a) in certain cases. The section discusses the alternative depreciation system and its limitations on property not predominantly used in a trade or business. It applies to property acquired after December 31, 2007, and before January 1, 2009, with specific conditions on acquisition dates. The alternative depreciation system applies to property acquired after December 31, 2007, and before January 1, 2009, with specific conditions on acquisition dates. The acquisition must be pursuant to a written contract entered into after December 31, 2007, and before January 1, 2009, and placed in service in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. Sec. 168A allows for high productivity investment deduction. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2007, for taxable years starting after that date. Additionally, Section 3 provides a 50 percent allowance for depreciation for certain property acquired during 2008. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change bonus percentages and dates for certain property. Basis limitations for specific property are repealed, and syndications are addressed in the code. These changes apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2007. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change bonus percentages and dates for certain property, including syndications. Property sold within 6 months of being placed in service after December 31, 2007, will have its service date adjusted accordingly. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2007, with an exception for property covered by the Gulf Opportunity Zone Act of 2005. SEC. 4. DEPRECIATION RULES NOT MODIFIED FOR ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX. The amendments made by this section exclude property placed in service in 2008 or 2009 from certain depreciation rules for alternative taxable income and adjusted current earnings. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2007, in taxable years beginning after that date. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to apply the percentage of completion method for long-term contract accounting. SEC. 6 allows long-term unused credits against minimum tax. In General, subsection (c) of section 53 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to add a special rule for corporations with long-term unused credits. If a corporation subject to section 56(g) has a long-term unused minimum tax credit, the allowable credit for the taxable year shall not exceed the greater of the limitation determined under paragraph (1) or the sum of the tax imposed by section 55 and the regular tax reduced. The text discusses the long-term unused minimum tax credit and the calculation of the credit based on qualified investment and carryover amounts. It also mentions the special rule for corporations with long-term unused credits against minimum tax. The long-term unused minimum tax credit is determined based on adjusted net minimum tax for specific taxable years. Credits are allowed on a first-in, first-out basis, with qualified investment and carryover amounts playing a role in the calculation. The qualified investment carryover is the excess of 50 percent of qualified investment over the tax amount in paragraph (2)(A)(ii)(I). It can only be carried over to the next taxable year after the current year, and the provision terminates for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The provision for qualified investment carryover terminates for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. Section 53(c) of the Code is amended to restructure paragraphs (1) and (2) as subparagraphs (A) and (B).
